div.p: 1. IV. Sun rose 4.40— Walk 1/2 an hour— Garden

I planted in my Eastern bed 10 black 11. red Cherry Stones. 18 almond in shell and 6. unshelled— In the South bed where I planted nuts and acorns last November and December none of which have come up; while weeding it with my own hands I left growing several plants which came up spontaneously, and the growth of which I inclined to observe— There are many wild cherry trees, sprung from Stones dropped last Summer from an old tree standing near the bed— They came up about the first of May— Then a plant of Lettuce— Then four poppies— Mustard— Anthemis, and two or three more. This morning the first flower of the Anthemis opened— It is like whiteweed. I read in Du Hamel on sowing and planting, and on the physics of trees— In Loudon’s encyclopaedia of gardening. page 158. I find a description of the germination of seed— Looked into Nicholson’s Encyclopaedia, Article Botany; and Eaton’s Manual. Mr Randolph came to apply for an Office. Mr Van Wyck, brother to the member of the 18th. Congress came with the same purpose— Said he regretted that his brother had declined accepting an appointment offered him as keeper of a Light House— Governor Barbour called; returned last evening from a visit to Baltimore to see Maelzel’s autometon Chess-player. Mr Willard is an inhabitant of Roxbury Street, adjoining to Boston, an eminent Clock-maker and has now been a Month at Mr Jefferson’s University setting a Clock, which he had been employed by Mr Jefferson, before his decease, to make— The cost he says is 1200 dollars. He is to set up one for the Corporation of New-York, which will cost 2000 dollars— He told me he made the old family Clock, at my father’s house. He is now 74 years of age. Dr May and Mr Ingle came as a Committee from the Residents on Capitol Hill—requesting that the building for the fire-engine and Hose at the Capitol may be located on the Hill, and not as some other persons desire, at the foot of the hill— They assigned very sufficient reasons for preferring the summit, although they mentioned that Mr Bulfinch thought otherwise— I promised to see Mr Elgar on the subject. Dr Todsen came again to solicit the vacant Clerkship in the War Department. Said he had applied to Governor Barbour, who said he should attempt to go on with the business of the Department without supplying that vacancy— Todsen urged my interposition in his favour— I declined unless Governor Barbour should himself consult me— He did speak to me of Todsen’s application, and of his own intention not to fill the vacated office for the present— Mr Rush mentioned that Captain Smith, the Engineer sent to inspect the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal works had returned, and made him a general verbal report, to be followed by an elaborate one in writing. Not so bad as we had reason to fear, but not very favourable— He also offered for adjustment the account of Mr Wirt, for his attendance at the Circuit Court at Philadelphia in the Thompson tea cases, all of which have been decided against the Government— Mr Clay sent me the draught of Instructions to H. Wheaton, as Chargé d’Affaires to Denmark which I read and sent back to the Department. He had also a reply from Mr Rebello, translated by himself and containing some exceptionable expressions; which we thought would make it necessary for Mr Clay to see him again. Mr Clay recommended W. Tudor to take C. Raguet’s place, and that the appointment should be speedily made— I incline to the same opinion— Mr Brent came for the Instructions to Mr Wheaton— Mr Southard had a Letter from Commodore Rodgers referring to a complaint from Mr Vaughan, the British Minister, that a guard-boat from Rodger’s Squadron, at Gibraltar, had hailed an English King’s ship— Rodgers vindicates his conduct, with great indignation at the complaint— By a Letter from Commodore Chauncey, it appears that Mr Sands had fenced in part of the Navy-Yard Lands at Brooklyn, and the Commodore has fenced out Mr Sands— The title must be tried. Southard had also fresh complaints against Midshipmen Green and Penhallow at Boston— Governor Kent of Maryland called and paid me a short visit—
2. IV— Sun rose 4:39— Garden talk with Ouseley.

Shortened my walk to the Tyber Square; and spent two hours in the garden, chiefly in conversation with Ouseley, who is an excellent and scientific gardener— The garden is small, and I would avail myself of the opportunity of becoming acquainted with the principal plants which it produces— Part of it has been abandoned to the weeds; and is overrun with them— There is a large weeping willow at the South-eastern corner, just within the fence, and on one side of the arched gate opening upon Pennsylvania avenue another willow of the same size is on the South side of the gate, and outside of the garden fence— Within the fence, on the South side of the garden, but North of the strip overrun with weeds is a row of well grown trees—a Tulip, a Red mulbery—two Ashes, and one Cornus Florida Dogwood— Near the turn of the Southwest Corner is a large wild cherry-tree— I found among the weeds, dock, plantain, Asters, Wild poppies, and plants which he called Shepherd’s purse, and Sour thistle—thence visiting the cultivated part, in a patch North of the middle alley, were Rue, Wormwood, Balm, Sage, Targon, Vervain, Mint, and Tansy— The Artichoke was in another quarter, and of flowers I retained the names of Hybiscus, African Marygold, Broadleaved Sage, and the Shrub Sbiria, improperly called Snow-Ball— These are perhaps not one in a hundred of the plants vegetating in the garden—a plant of which numbers are within the last week coming up in my seed bed, he told me was the Althea— I planted 23. Black-heart cherries in my eastern bed. Then returning to my Study read a few pages of the Preface to Du Hamel on planting— There is much good information in the Book— Mr Van Wyck came, and informed me that as his brother had declined to accept the appointment which was offered him of keeper of a Light House, he himself would gladly accept a similar appointment for one now building and which he understood be finished, and ready for a keeper next September— I told him I would bear it in mind— He said that his brother had involved him in his misfortunes, and was now keeping a school in some part of Pennsylvania— Mr Southard came to say that he had sometime since engaged a Vessel at Norfolk, to carry to the African Colony a number of negroes adjudicated to the United States, as having been illegally imported— Twelve had been taken in at Norfolk and the vessel had proceeded to Savannah in Georgia, there to take in upwards of a hundred more— Dr Peaco, a Surgeon in the Navy had been employed as the agent to have charge of them for their conveyance to Africa, but a few days after his arrival at Savannah he was taken sick and died— The vessel which by the engagement was to be only twenty days at Savannah, had already been there that time, and now remains at a charge of demurrage to the Public, and Mr Southard said he did not know whom to employ in the place of Dr Peaco— I mentioned to him Dr Todsen, as a professional Surgeon, accustomed to Southern Climates, and perhaps as well suited to this service, as any person, who could now be selected— I told him of the circumstances under which he had been dismissed from the service and his continual applications to be restored to it— I referred him to Mr Wirt, for a further account of Todsen’s character; observing that as I believed all his misfortunes had originated in the badness of his temper, that would constitute the principal objection to his appointment— Mr Southard said he would make enquiries of Mr Wirt; and then confer with me again. Dr. Watkins and Mr Barney, the naval Officer at Baltimore came on a visit together. Coll. Roberdeau came to give me the true time; having taken an observation at Noon with W. Elliot on Capitol Hill. It agreed within a minute, with my own observation of the rising Sun this Morning. Mr Skinner came to say he had received a Letter from Mr C Willey of Connecticut, mentioning his wish to be appointed Collector at Middletown, when the vacancy occurs in that Office which must be very shortly. I had received similar Letters from Mr Willey himself, and told Mr Skinner that the only possible objection to his appointment was his being a member of Congress— That would be a difficulty— Mr Clay and Mr Rush called together— Mr Clay with a revised note from Mr Rebello, which are thought acceptable, and Mr Rush with the papers of a new application for a remission of penalties upon a British Vessel, arrived with an excess of passengers—children— Miss Roberdeau left us and returned home this Evening. I wrote to George.
3. IV. Sun rose 4:39.

I finished this morning reading the Preface to Du Hamel’s Treatise upon sowing and planting. It contains a summary of the whole work, which is in six books, forming a Quarto Volume of about 400 pages besides the preface which is of 68— The first book treats of the Soils adapted to different trees. The second of the various modes of raising trees. The third of Nurseries and Batardicres— The fourth of Plantations from the Nursery. The fifth of raising Forests. And the sixth of the preservation and restoration of decayed Woods— The Summary itself gives me a favourable idea of the contents of the work, and many things are new to me, which I ought to have known at least half a century— One considerable difficulty is the nomenclature— Numerous words not to be found in the Dictionary of the Academy, and some which when found are not intelligibly defined— The writer is however clear, and there are many plates in the work, more explanatory than any description could be. I have suspended the Physique des Arbres, to take up this book. Heard Mr Little from Ecclesiastes 6.11. [“]Seeing there be many things that increase vanity, what is man the better? 12 For who knoweth what is good for man in this life, all the days of his vain life which he spendeth as a shadow? for who can tell a man what shall be after him under the sun?” Mr Little explained the meaning of the term Vanity, as used in the Scriptures, and particularly in the Book of Ecclesiastes, observing that it was different from the sense in which the same word is now in common discourse applied to the character of persons. And he then gave a picture of the miseries and afflictions incident to human life in illustration of this Sentiment in the text, which is indeed the prevailing doctrine of that book— It is easy to fill up this outline— There is a natural disposition in man to brood over his afflictions, and to make himself more unhappy than he is— The Scriptures have added the sanction of religion to this Sentiment, and present the condition of man, as wretched because it is fallen— In the heathen mythology the moral and physical condition of man was represented as having undergone gradual depravation, but the variety of human life is not inculcated among the moralists of Greece and Rome— The Satyrist Persius says

lg.l: “O Curas Hominum! o quantum est in rebus inane!”

div.p: but in that Poet and still more in Juvenal, there are many traces of the influence of Christian ideas upon the opinions of the age—an influence, of which while it acted upon them they were themselves unconscious. Mr Little closed his discourse however by admitting that the condition of human life was now much happier than it was in the days of Solomon— I have no doubt—but whether taking an average of individuals there is more enjoyment, or more suffering now than then— Of sensual pleasure no man now living can have enjoyed more than fell to the lot of Solomon— None can have been favoured with higher, nobler, more varied, or longer continued intellectual gratifications— And he contributed as much perhaps as man that ever lived to that very improvement in the Condition of his Species— But he was satiated with happiness, and after a youth of supernatural wisdom; and a manhood of unrivalled glory he wasted his old age in blasted, and impotent excitement; in idolatrous dotage, and in helpless repining at the nothingness of the delights which he could no longer relish— His wives and concubines found him as Madame de Maintenon found Louis 14. a not amusable man— With health of body and of mind, human life is in truth a condition of happiness in the main, interrupted by frequent sorrows. And while we assent with humble reverence to the estimates of life formed by unerring wisdom, we are not the less bound to receive and acknowledge with gratitude the blessings with which divine Providence has gladdened our existence— A Storm of rain, confined me at home, from the time of the morning service for the rest of the day— Antoine brought me as a present from Mr Jullien six Silk worms: three black, and three nearly white, one of which was beginning, and one preparing to spin the web around him—
4. IV. Round Capitol Square— Showery.

The rains of yesterday and last Night, turned me to my usual Winter’s walk round the Capitol Square, which as the Season advances has become a dull one— Upon my return a heavy Shower, excluded me from the garden— The Silk worm which commenced its web yesterday, had completely surrounded himself this morning, but was yet visible through the cocoon all this day— The two other black ones went into the same state last Night and this day. The web of the first is a bright golden yellow; those of the second and third are nearly white— I read the first Chapter of Du Hamel on Plantation— Upon the Soil suitable for Trees; which shews that judgment must be used in adapting the trees to be planted to the Soils in which they are to grow— He considers the soil not only of and near the surface, but even as deep as the roots of the trees will delve, as subject of grave consideration. The trees of wet and dry soils, of clay sand and gravel, of chalk and of Stone— The trees for large forests, and for low thickets for groves and arbours for hedges and walls, for warren’s, and partridge coves—shrubbery or single Standard, are all discriminated, and a description and engraving are given of an Auger (Tariere) to bore the earth six, eight, or ten feet deep, and thence bring up a sample of the stratum of earth there hidden— He gives it as a general rule, that whatever the soil near the surface may be, if rock or chalk be found within the depth to which the roots strike, the tree will be stunted— I examine my three flower Pots almost every hour of the day to witness the process of vegetation. George M. Bourne came suddenly this morning again to solicit a place— He is one of the two Sons of Sylvanus Bourne, many years Consul at Amsterdam, and has been seven or eight years— In the interval he has been twice or three times to France and Holland, to New-Orleans, to New-Harmony and I know not where— Always a burden upon Charity, and always coming back to represent himself at death’s door, to be saved from perishing only by an office— His condition is pitiable— I advised him to go and fix himself somewhere— To exert himself to obtain a subsistence as others do, and quietly to wait, till there may be an opportunity to do something for him— While he was here came Madame Coulon, Mother to Andrew Armstrong who has been Consular Agent at Port au Prince in the Island of St. Domingo. The Government there having repeatedly demanded to be recognized, and we having declined to comply with that request, finally refused to consider him as the authorised Agent of the United States, upon which he was some Months since ordered to come home— He has not yet arrived but his mother now came to solicit another place for him, suggesting and urging that her subsistence depended greatly upon him— I told her that I would do for her Son what might be in my power— Mr Rush came and took the papers in the case of the British Barque Lord Wellington, the forfeiture of which for bringing a number of Passengers beyond that authorised by the Law, I have ordered to be remitted. Mr Southard read me a Letter from Mr Sands of New-York, complaining that Commodore Chauncey had taken military possession of the Land at the Navy-Yard, the title to which is claimed by him, and also that his Letter proposing to refer the question to arbitrators had not been answered— I advised that an answer should immediately be sent him, declining an arbitration— Stating that the title of the United States to the Land is believed to be good; and that if his claim and those of other individuals to parts of the Land can be sustained, it must be settled by the Courts of Law— Southard spoke also of Dr Todsen, concerning whom he had made enquiries, and had received various information, which he thought upon the whole rendered the appointment of him to the African Agency of doubtful expediency. Todsen himself was afterwards here, and had heard from some person that his name had been mentioned by me to Mr Southard, for this appointment— He was extremely anxious to obtain it— I referred him to Mr Southard, but without giving him any encouragement— He came again after seeing Mr Southard; and said he believed he should obtain the place— This evening, at the request of the Governor and Legislative Council of the Michigan Territory, I remitted a fine imposed by the Superior Court of the Territory upon Jeremiah Van Rensselaer Ten Eyck, for a contempt; and I confirmed the appointments of three keepers of Light Houses at the Recommendation of the fifth Auditor S. Pleasonton.
5. IV. Sun rose 4:38. Potowmac Bath— Garden visit. 36 White Heart Cherry Stones

Although the morning was cold, I bathed and swam about ten minutes from the rock, alone— Then spent two hours in the garden, where at every visit enquiries multiply upon me— In this small garden of less than two Acres, there are forest and fruit trees, shrubs, hedges, esculent vegetables, kitchen and Medicinal herbs, hot house plants, flowers and weeds, to the amount I conjecture of at least one thousand. One half of them perhaps are common weeds, most of which have none but the botanical name— I ask the name of every plant I see— Ousley the Gardener knows almost all of them by their botanical names, but the numbers to be discriminated, and recognized, are baffling to the memory, and confounding to the judgment— From the small patch where the medicinal herbs stand together I plucked this morning leaves of Balm, and Hyssop, Marjoram, Mint, Rue, Sage, Tansy, Targon, and Wormwood, one half of which were known to me only by the name— The Tarragon, not even by that— I read the second chapter of Du Hamel, upon the climate and exposition, adapted to different trees— He divides them generally into mountain and valley trees, and marks the quarters of the compass to be considered in fixing their various sites— Eckloff the Tailor was here professionally— Dr Lewis Beers comes from the western part of the State of New York, and brought me a Letter of Introduction from David Woodcock, dated at Ithaca. A Stranger was with him whose name was not mentioned— J. J. Meyer is a young man from Saint Gal, in Switzerland, who said he was introduced to me last Winter by Mr Cazenove of Alexandria, which I had forgotten— He has been travelling through the Western and some of the Southern States, and to the Havana— And is now on his return to Europe: with the intention as he says of coming back in two or three years to settle in this Country. Mr Lowrie, the Secretary of the Senate, made a short visit, being upon some official business in the City— Mr Handy who some time since applied for the appointment of two of his Sons, one as a Cadet and the other as a midshipman, came to say, that he gave up the first of these applications, to urge with reinforced energy the other. Mr Clay came with Condy Raguet, late Charge d’Affaires of the United States at Rio de Janeiro— He gave me some new particulars of his motives for demanding his Passports, without orders from his Government, and coming away. He thinks that the Spirit and energy of his proceedings alarmed the Government of Brazil—and induced them to offer that promise of satisfaction for all just complaints which they have made through their Charge d’Affaires here, Rebello; and he said that he hoped the Confidence which I had so often shewn him would not be withdrawn— I told him that my opinion of his integrity, patriotism and zeal, was unimpaired—that I was convinced of the purity of his motives to the steps he had taken but that I had thought it would have been better, if he had before taking that step Consulted his Government. Mr Calvert and his son George paid a visit upon their return from Europe— Mr Southard called, with the draught of a Letter to Mr. Sands declining the reference of the question of title to the Navy Yard Lands at Brooklyn to arbitrators— Mr Rush brought a claim from the Administrators of Athanasius Fenwick a Collector in Maryland, for fees paid to Counsel for defending a suit brought against him for a seizure, in which he was ultimately justified— He had also a correspondence with the Collector at Bristol, Drury who retains public monies too long in his hands, and to whom a peremptory order is to be transmitted to pay over the money immediately— Likewise some question about the appointment of B. Hook as deputy Collector again at Castine— Letter from S. K. Gilman, assigning his reasons for the appointment, which is to be confirmed. Mr Clay brought translation of a long note from Salmon, Chargé d’Affaires of Spain, complaining of Commodore Porters proceedings at Key West, as violating the neutrality of the United States— Cabinet Meeting to be at 1. on Thursday— John R. Penniman here this Eve a Painter from Boston—
6. IV:10. Swam from the Boat— 10 minutes— Garden Stroll— 36. White Heart Cherry Stones—sown—

My bath was again alone, and cold— My garden stroll becoming anxious— I examined the weeds which have grown up in one small Strawberry bed, set out by the gardener last Autumn— They amount to ten or twelve conspicuous and prevalent—Amaranth, Ambrosia, Buckwheat, Broad and narrow leaved Dock— Goosefoot or Hogweed, Knot-grass, broad and narrow leaved Plantain, Shepherd’s purse, and Thorn-apple, or Datura Stramonium; and Veronica; or Speedwell— A few only of these are in blossom, and many repetitions both of the sight of the plant and of the name it bears, are necessary to fix almost every one of them distinctly in my mind— I was thus occupied till breakfast time and had none for reading Du Hamel— I had sent for Mr Elgar, and I spoke with him concerning the City Surveyor; he did not think himself authorised to make any payments to him from public funds— He considers him now as a Corporation Officer, to be compensated by fees, or at the charge of the City, though he had given him a commission, under an opinion of the Circuit Court of the District that this was necessary to the legality of his appointment. I mentioned the application of Mr Matthews, and R. C. Weightman, as a Committee from the Washington Library Society, for Land on which to erect the building for keeping their books— He said there might be a sale to them at an easy price, unless they should wish some of the reserved Lands, not intended for sale— I desired him to see Mr Matthews and ascertain from him, where they wished to place their building— I referred also to the application from Dr May, and Mr Ingle, in behalf of the House holders on the Capitol Hill, concerning the location of the Engine-House, to be erected for keeping the Fire-Engine, for the use of the Capitol— Mr Carroll was the only person who objected to its being on the top of the Hill; because it will intercept the view of the Capitol, from a corner house there belonging to him— He said all the other inhabitants on the hill being anxious to have the building at the summit, Mr Carroll had withdrawn his objection; and nevertheless still urged that when he had built his house, it was with the expectation that the space between it and the Capitol would always remain open— I told Mr Elgar that the convenience to the Capitol and the neighbourhood was obviously so much greater in having the building at the top of the hill, and there being only one objector to many Petitioners, the objection too being ostensibly withdrawn, I thought the building should be erected on the top of the Hill— Elgar told me he had at Mr Foy’s request, fenced round, a plot of the yard west of the House for my use as a Nursery for trees and plants— Dr Todsen came again to say that he had heard of Mr Southard’s objections to appointing him to the agency vacated by the Death of Dr Peaco, and he made an argument to prove his fitness for the place— I told him that Mr Southard had probably made other arrangements, and that I believed he must wait until there should be some other opportunity for employing him— Mr Raguet came, and observing that he should leave the City to-morrow Morning to return to Philadelphia, read me several Letters, relating to his departure from Rio de Janeiro and some to sustain his opinion that the Government there, will be shortly overthrown— One of the Letters was from Mr Gordon the British Minister, who had been long confined by illness to his chamber; but who expressing great regret at his intended departure, and a candid opinion that the step he had taken was stronger than the circumstances would justify tendered his friendly good offices to produce a reconciliation so as to avert his departure— His answer which he also read declined accepting this interposition, unless he should be assured it was desired by the Brazilian Government, which Mr Gordon of course could not state— He said he had afterwards a personal interview with Mr Gordon, from whom he parted upon the most friendly terms. He said he had been well aware that the step he had taken was one of very great responsibility; but he was yet confident that nothing short of it would have prevailed upon the Brazilian Government, to give us any satisfaction for their numerous wrongs— Mr Hebb is an old applicant for Office, who had heard of the vacant Clerkship in the War Department, and who could not perceive the expediency of the Secretary of Wars forbearance to fill the place immediately. Mr Brent called for papers relating to the remissions of penalties and forfeitures.
7. IV. Swam from the Boat— Garden— 28 red Cherry-stones— 15 Strawberries.

The mornings are yet cool, and the river water cold, but as the morning tide serves I dive from the boat, alone, and swim to the shore— The tide being this morning high I ascended the bluff, and plucked a weed, which my living dictionary Ousley told me was yarrow— I took also from the fields a plant of common woolly Mullein, which I knew and compared it with the moth Mullein in the garden, a totally different plant. There are two plants one of which Ousley called Comefry, and the other Grounsel which were altogether unknown to me— The Palma Christi, from which Castor Oil is made I had seen and known but forgotten— The leaves of Plants are extremely imperfect, and somewhat deceptive tests of discrimination— That is reserved to the flower, of which a small proportion are in bloom at one time— I planted this morning a few ripe strawberries to ascertain if their seeds would vegetate— I had time to read only a very few pages of Du Hamel in the third chapter on the choice of the kinds of trees to be planted— Adapting the tree to the soil and the site, and with views of economy and of profit— Dr Todsen came again to press for the Agency to Africa, but I told him I could no further interfere in the Appointment. Mr Skinner came and introduced Coll. Buel from Connecticut as a Visitor— There was a Cabinet Meeting attended by Messrs.Clay, Rush and Southard—Governor Barbour not having yet returned from his excursion to Annapolis and Baltimore and Mr Wirt being absent— The questions considered were, what should be done upon Mr. Salmon the Spanish Charge d’Affaires’s complaint of violations of neutrality by Commodore Porter. It was deemed important to prevent him from making use of his station at Key-West for annoyance against Spain— But of the precise authority of the Executive to restrain him by force, and of the mod in which it should be exercised were much discussed— It was finally concluded that the Secretary of the Treasury should write to the Collector at Key west, directing him generally not to permit any violation of neutrality by the Commodore, and particularly that he should not be allowed to fit out his prizes there as privateers; and then ordering them to return there with their prizes, and that he should not be allowed to arm and in any manner increase his force there— Instructions are to be given by the Secretary of the Navy to the Commander of our West India Squadron to touch occasionally at Key West and give to the Collector any aid of force that he may need to enforce his discharge of his duties; the Instructions to the Collector and those to the Commander of the Squadron, are to be adapted to each other, and the answer by Mr Clay to Mr Salmon is to be conformable to them— Attention is however to be given to two important points—one to authorize no act of force of doubtful legality— The other not to endanger the life and health of the men in our public ships, by requiring them to remain any length of time at this and the approaching Season of the year at key West. I requested Mr Clay to answer a Letter that I have received from Governor Abraham Lincoln of Maine— Mr Southard mentioned to me that he had not yet fixed upon his Agent to go to Africa, but he is immovable in his rejection of Todsen. Miss Selina Roberdeau came to spend some days with Mrs Adams— Mr David Baker, the Minister of the Presbyterian Church called this Evening; just returned from a meeting of the Clergy of that denomination at Philadelphia— He intimated that there was a probability of his leaving the Church here, and succeeding an old gentleman as Pastor of a Mariners Church in Philadelphia— He spoke of this however as at present a secret, and as merely probable—
8. III:30. Swam from the boat— 15 minutes— Garden. 28. red cherry stones.

I had a bad night—little repose, and by a feverish restlessness rose from bed at half past three— But I have no time that I can employ, ever hanging upon my hands— As soon as there was daylight enough to allow me to read, I finished Du Hamel’s third Chapter and first Book on planting— His remarks on Mountain Trees—on Whitewoods and aquatic trees— Of trees for alleys in Gardens and Parks—for Palissades and Arbours for warrens and coveys—for Massive Forests, Avenues, High ways Hedges and Quincunxes, all have their interest, though not all suited to the taste of the Age, and some of them not to the usages of this Country— The principles are applicable to all times, and to every Country— For the perfection of the tree, it should be suited to the soil and climate where it is to grow—for purposes of economy, plantations should be made for the profit to be derived from them— The uses of plants and trees are numberless, for all the comforts, and enjoyments of civilized life, and they are adaptable to every stage of civilization— At five I went to the boat, and swam about 15 minutes to the Shore— Then visited the garden, and noticed the patch where the seedling esculent vegetables were in blossom— The deep blood coloured beet, the white flowered carrot, and yellow flowered Parsnip— The enormous leaved Horse radish, and the tall and Slender stemmed Jerusalem Artichoke—with those numerous weeds are growing in rank luxuriance; though I found none new— I appealed again to my nomenclator, the gardener for the names of various weeds which he had told me before, but which I had forgotten, and fixed some of them more determinately in my mind— I put 28 red cherry stones into the ground. I was out upwards of three hours, and wrote to G: G Barrell at Malaga, requesting him to send me some Spanish Chesnuts and Cork-Oak Acorns— Mr Bussard came and introduced a Mr Baker of Frederick County, Maryland, a Farmer whose visit was of mere curiosity— Mr Karthaus of Baltimore came in behalf of a Company engaged in the project of opening a road from Milesburg to Smethport, one of the new western communications— His object now was to obtain the assignment by the Government of the United States of an Engineer to assist them in their Surveys; for which I referred him to the Secretary of War— Mr Reed of Philadelphia, called to visit me, and afterwards with his Son dined with us— He said he came to accompany Mrs Bradford, widow of the former Attorney General of the United States on a visit to Mrs Coxe of Georgetown— Mr Brent brought me a draught of a Proclamation declaring the suspension of the discriminating duties, upon vessels and their Cargoes belonging to the subjects of his Holiness the Pope— But he had erroneously copied the former Proclamations founded on the act of 3 March 1815 which is repealed. I told him it must be founded on the act of 7. January 1824. read to him the fourth Section of the Act, and directed that the Proclamation should follow it as far as possible word for word— W. E. Stark was a young man from Norfolk Virginia, soliciting an appointment as a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps; he brought me a Letter of Introduction from T. Newton— Mr Clay was here this Evening— He proposes to leave the City on Sunday for a visit to Kentucky, intending to return here by the first of August— I found myself unable to write, the greater part of this day— My health and Spirits droop, and the attempt to sustain them, by exciting an anxious interest in Botany, the natural History of Trees, and the purpose of naturalizing exotics, is almost desperate. The design is fascinating, but the practical execution is beset with difficulties— One of them is the consumption of time in search of knowledge on the subject— I seek it blindfold, and now with an anxiety which causes sleepless Nights— I began last Summer with Michaux’s North-American Sylva, and formed some little acquaintance with the Oaks, but learnt little or nothing of the best manner of cultivating them— This Summer I have more books— But with them the objects of enquiry, and investigation spread— I believe ten Summers, of unrelaxing attention will be necessary to accomplish any thing useful for posterity, and after all it may terminate in disappointment— This night I change my bedchamber, in the hope of obtaining less unquiet sleep, and more repose.
9. III.45 Sun rose 4:37. Swam from the Boat— Garden— 12 red cherry-stones

The first decided Summers day— Began reading Du Hamel’s second Book on Plantation— On the various modes of propagating trees— 1. By seed. 2. By slips. 3 by layers 4. by Suckers. 5. by grafting— The first he recommends as the best, although you are never sure of raising the same variety that is planted— The second chapter treats of trees which are raised by slips—the third by layers: the fourth by suckers, and the fifth by grafting; and budding— On going out about five, I measured by pacing the four sides of the ground just fenced in for my use as a Nursery— I count 2 1/2 feet to each of my paces, and by this rule I find the enclosure contains 1 1/5 Acre not quite. I swam from the boat about a quarter of an hour and then visited my garden beds. I found one of my casual poppies in flower a dark violet with a Corolla, of four Petals— The mustard is also in flower and has attained a height of five feet— The wild cherries which came up about the first of May, are none of them more than four inches high— The Altheas are coming up every day—the first appeared about the 20th. of May, and the Seed leaves were open about ten days before the leaf proper pushed forth. As Mr Ousley was not in the garden I had no opportunity of adding to the Stock of my acquaintance among the weeds. Mr Southard called to speak further of his selection for an African Agent— He now thinks of a temporary Agent merely for the transportation of the Negroes to the Colony; reserving time for the Selection of a suitable permanent Agent— He has been expecting these six weeks the arrival of the Cyane Captain Elliot from the Coast of Brazil, and had destined that vessel to the cruise this Summer, to protect the fisheries and along the coast of Labrador— Albright is a young man from Pennsylvania, who came to shew me a Rifle fowling piece, the Stock of which was worked in a finical manner, by himself and for which he asked 150 dollars— My admiration of his ingenuity was not so satisfactory to him, as it would have been, if I had purchased his musket— Mr Brent came for the Note of Mr Clay in answer to Mr Salmons complaint, concerning Commodore Porters violations of neutrality. Mr Clay had left it with me last Evening— Mr Morton of Bordeaux came as a visitor and Mr Delaplaine a Maryland Farmer. Governor Barbour called, having returned last Evening from his excursion to Baltimore and Annapolis, and Mr Bozley’s premium farm, of which he speaks in high admiration— He had a public dinner given to him at Annapolis; with toasts and speeches as usual— Mr Clay called this Evening and took leave. Going for Kentucky to-morrow— Heavy Thunder shower this evening.
10. III:45. Sun rose 4:36. Garden Stroll

Heard Mr Little, this morning from Ecclesiastes 3:11. [“]He hath made every thing beautiful in his time: also he hath set the world in their heart, so that no man can find out the work that God maketh from the beginning to the end”— There was a connection between this discourse and that of last Sunday Morning. In this text there is an obscurity of expression, which Mr Little did not attempt to explain— There is an apparent disconnection between the premises and the conclusion—the words he hath set the world in their heart convey an indistinct idea— The Latin vulgate and the German Translations say more intelligibly—“He makes every thing good in its time; and lets their heart perplex itself, how it shall go in the world—for man cannot indeed find out the work that God does—neither beginning nor end[”]— Thomson’s translation of the Septuagint changes entirely the thought and says “All the things which he made, considered as a whole, are good in his time. But with regard to all things considered as one whole, to them he hath assigned the whole age so that no man can find out the work which God hath done from beginning to end.” This is a paraphrase; more obscure than the common English translation, and refined almost into nonsense— The text is in the middle of the Chapter which commences with the assertion that to every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under heaven— The thought in the 11th verse seems to be—every thing is good in its time— Men make them selves anxiously busy with prying into the management of the world, but it is beyond the reach of human enquiry. This
is intelligible enough, and corresponds with the purport of the whole chapter, and of the Book. Mr Little dwelt principally upon the last clause of the verse—the absurdity of attempting to account for things from the beginning to the end— In the afternoon I heard Mr Baker from Joshua 22.20. [“]Did not Achan the son of Zerah commit a trespass in the accursed thing, and wrath fell on all the congregation of Israel? and that man perished not alone in his iniquity.” Mr Baker told the whole story of Achan’s trespass and of his punishment; but this text is only an allusion to it by Joshua, when first informed of the proposal of the two and a half tribes, to settle on the East side of the Jordan, and he supposed they intended to separate themselves from the rest of the tribes and renounce their religion— Mr Baker’s train of thought was in that direction— The trespass in the accursed thing to him was infidelity—and infidelity was a disbelief of the atonement— His zeal is very ardent and very sincere— In the Evening I heard Mr Little again— It was within one day of the fifth anniversary since the opening of this Church; and he took the occasion for a renewed exposition of the Unitarian doctrines— His text was from Ephesians 4:15 “Speaking the truth, in love”— There was of course little more than a Summary of the opinions which he has been during that time inculcating— He said however it had been alleged that he had changed his ground; that the character of the principles which he now maintained was not the same with that of the system upon which he had commenced— This he very explicitly denied, and in proof of the denial, he read a large extract from the Sermon which he preached at the dedication of the Church— The allegation itself of any change in the complexion of his discourses seems to me quite unfounded— I walked this morning in the garden, and after dinner round the grounds in front of the House— Found the second of my poppies in blossom— A single flower, the petals of a delicate carnation colour— My attention is turning to the Suckers from some of the trees, and I first noticed one from the paper mulberry which may be set out the next Autumn— I read part of Du Hamel’s Chapter 6. of Book 2. on the propogation of trees by seeds— With a description of the different kinds of Seeds, and of the signs by which they are known to be ripe— Read also a few pages of Locke’s outlines of Botany, and turned over the pages of Loudon’s Encyclopaedia of gardening— The warmth of the day was oppressive.
11. III.45. Sun rose 4:36— Garden.

The weeds are encroaching so much upon my seed bed that I had them spaded up, by Antoine. I wished also to give the last chance to the nuts and acorns that I planted last winter to make their appearance— The Chesnuts, I suspect have been devoured by worms attacking them from without— Two of the shagbark nuts I have found vegetating, but they were perhaps planted too deep, for none of them have reached the surface— A third of my casual poppies was this morning in bloom— Its colour intermediate between the two others— The young wild cherries seem stationary; but the Altheas are every day coming up numerously and that of which I first noticed the seed leaves has put forth one pair of the leaves proper and is elaborating a second— My reading in Du Hamel was interrupted this day, but I read some pages of M’Mahon’s Gardening, and some of Lockes Outlines of Botany. Of the seeds which I planted in three flower pots the 27th of May, one this day made its appearance on the surface raised by its radical, and working off its leathery shell— An apple pepper, and its appearance is on the fifteenth day from its being sown. Mr Frye called here, and asked to see the Bond given by the Commissioner of the public Buildings; which he thought was lodged with me; but it was not. He has a question with the Commissioner respecting his title to some lots in the City, purchased of the Public and said he should have to go into Chancery for them— He was called away before he had stated to me as he intended the merits of his claim. Wyer came to favour me with his Conversation, and told me he had thoughts of going to England, that he might have something to do. Governor Barbour brought me voluminous papers, being proceedings of a Court-Martial, upon six Cadets at West-Point the decision upon which he wished to have as soon as might be— Five of the six are sentenced to be dismissed, but with recommendations in favour of two of them, that the punishment should be remitted— There was a concert this Evening, attended by part of the family— My apple seed, by the growth of the day was raised just above the surface of the ground—
12. III:45. Sun rose Cloud-veiled. Garden walk only

Antoine has an exotic plant which he calls the laurel rose, in a large tub of Earth— Besides the main stem it has now two additional shoots which he prepared this morning for transplanting, according to what he calls the Chinese method, and which he says he learnt in a book. He made a slit transversely in the stem to be transplanted, say two inches above its junction with the main stem put a small peg into the slit to keep it from closing again—passed a glass bottle over the stem to be removed, with its neck and bottom both broken off; fixed the bottle so as to rest below the slit and the stem and just as its junction with the root and then stuffed the bottle with earth, which thus closed round the stem above and below the slit, and into which the stem will put out lateral roots above the slip—when these have acquired sufficient strength the stem is cut off from its junction with the old root, and transplanted to another tub or green house bed, adapted to a hole into which all the earth within the bottle is received, and the bottle itself is broken— My reading and observation were otherwise interrupted this day— Dr Todson came to thank me for the appointment which Mr Southard has finally concluded to give him of Agent for conveying the negroes to the African Colony. I observed to him that his future destiny would depend very much upon the propriety of his conduct under this appointment, and that I hoped it would be such as to justify the Government in appointing him, and as entirely to retrieve his character— He took leave for immediate departure— Mr Preuss came to solicit the appointment of Consul at Dantzig—which is his native City; but he has been residing many years in this Country. He proposes to form a commercial establishment there, and expects the trade with that Port, particularly from Baltimore. I told him I would consider of the matter, and requested him to call again, next week— Mr Van Wyck came again to renew his application for an appointment as a keeper of a Light House in the State of New-York. He is on his return from his excursion into Virginia— Mr Blount called; recently from New-York upon business— Mr Johnston, came to press for an appointment to Office, to save himself and a large family from famine— There is no vacancy— Mr Brent introduced Mr Morfit who has just been appointed to an informal commercial agency at Halifax, Nova Scotia—for which he gave thanks— Colonel Roberdeau brought the truetime, from an observation which he had been taking with William Elliot. I take the time by the rising of the Sun, when the sky is clear, with as much accuracy as by any possible meridian observation— On the first of this month I set my Chronometer made by French one hour in advance— I propose to make an allowance of one minute a week for its loss, and think with that the longitude might be taken with it, the year round, and the world round. The Box Chronometer that I have from the War Department is not so permanently regular— It was perfectly correct during the winter Months— But since April, has gained ten minutes. Governor Barbour came to speak of a vacant Indian Agency, for which he mentioned several competitors, among whom is Thomas Mann Randolph. He has just returned from his Agency to run the line between Georgia and Florida; the work was not effected, but it failed not by his fault— I advised the appointment of him. Mr Southard came and informed me of his arrangements for the African Agency; and his appointment of Dr Todsen— He sends him in the Cutter Florida, from this place to Savannah; stopping to take in some of the Negroes at Norfolk— There was an Evening party at Dr Watkins’s, attended by Mrs Adams and part of the family. I can no longer read or write in the Evening, and would devise means of useful occupation from the dusk till ten O’Clock— The apple pippin which appeared yesterday on the surface of the ground has been rising on its stalk, and working off its shell all this day, but has not yet cast it off— The process of vegetation, like all the works of Nature is astonishing when observed in its continual progress— I got through the examination of the proceedings of the Court Martial at West-Point, on six Cadets, for disorders on the 5th of May, and wrote the decisions.
13. III:30. Sun rose 4:35. Garden, and walk 1/2 an hour.

The attractions of the Garden, and the objects of curiosity constantly multiplying upon my attention there have rendered my walks abroad for mere exercise tedious, and irksome— So that I have omitted them the last three days— But this morning after planting in my eastern seed bed 18 whole red cherries, and visiting the Southern bed where the casual poppies are now all (six) in flower—the mustard and Anthemis in full blossom—the Althaeas still coming up, and the wild cherries apparently stationary. I remarked that the strawberries are ceasing, and the currants red and black becoming ripe— The Catalpa trees are in full and beautiful blossom, and the Holyoke’s Bladder Senna, and other flowers are blossoming— The rue, sage, and Hyssop are also in bloom— I remarked that the Honey Bees, had keen relish for the Poppy-flowers, and the wasps for the wormwood though not in blossom— The border of Thyme is still in full-bloom— I walked after leaving the garden, half way to College Hill— My Apple pippin in the flower pot, shed its shell, forty-eight hours after its first appearance on the surface of the ground— This seed must have been barely covered with the earth— I sowed several of them thus, and others as much as two inches deep— It was raised about half an inch above the surface, when the shell was ready to drop off; and the seed opened itself into two greenish seed leaves, with a plume already formed between them. I procured four small boxes for the purpose of preserving cherry stones and other seeds to be sown and planted next autumn and Spring— With the boxes, Antoine brought me two small apples of the present year, said to come from South-Carolina— Mr Blount called this morning, and afterwards dined with us— Selina Roberdeau left us, and returned home— Mr Rush came with a Letter from Dr. Mease, and a Supplementary list of plants to be imported from abroad. Mr Rush said he had given to Force, for publication, and extract from a book of Dr Lettsoms, containing directions for the transportation over sea, of delicate plants and seeds— Dr. Mease is now prosecuting enquiries, concerning the best modes of dying Silks, and wishes Mr Brown may be requested to enquire of the practice at the Gobelin Tapestry Makers in Paris— Mr Southard brought a Letter from Lieutt. Auchmuty of the Marine Corps, containing charges against Coll. R. Smith at New-York; the same on whose conduct there was a late Court of Enquiry. Mr Southard thought he must be tried— He had also Letters from a person at Portsmouth New-Hampshire named Parker, making statements very unfavourable to John P. Decatur, the Navy Agent there, and to acting Midshipman Penhallow. Mr Southard read me also his Letter of Instructions to Commodore Ridgley, and that of Mr Rush, to the Collector at Thompsons Island, Key West, respecting Commodore Porter’s alledged violations of the neutrality of our Territory. I suggested one alteration, and one addition to the Letter to Ridgley. My health still droops, especially every evening; and I had again very little sleep last Night, which made me drowsy, great part of this day— Borland put up my two bookshelves.
14. III:45.— Cloudy— Walk to foot of College Hill

Walked in the morning twilight, to the foot of College Hill, and plucked twigs from three Oaks standing there, for Mrs Adams to paint— A Post Oak—a Black jack, and one, the leaf of which differs from all those in Michaux; but I think it a variety of the Black Oak— It is one of the finest trees I ever saw— Umbrella formed— I should judge fifty feet high, and ten feet in circumference— These are all valuable Oaks, none of which grows in the vicinity of Boston— On my return I picked up in the road 8 small red cherries, the stones of which I propose to plant— In the garden I planted 10 whole Strawberries just covering them over with Earth— I found this morning a second apple pippin coming up in the flower pot— It had cast its shell before coming to the surface having been planted deeper than the other. It came up by a stem issuing from the germ and bent downwards—in the course of the day, the stem raised the split seed so that the two seed leaves or cotyledons presented their surface obliquely towards the light of the window— The plume made its first appearance— That of the first risen seed expanded itself into two leaves proper, showing still a feather shooting from them— The radicle and the plume spring from the same germ— The books say that the movement of the radicle is always downward, and that of the plume always upward— But it seems to be the radicle that throws up the seed leaves out of the ground— These however rise only high enough to unfold themselves to the Sun, and the plume shoots out from them like the inner tube of a spyglass from the outer one— I finished reading the second Book of Du Hamel on planting— The observations upon the various kinds of seeds, upon nurseries, upon propagating trees, by Suckers, layers, grafting and budding
are interesting, and to me most of them are new— His recommendation to cut off the tap root, of transplanted trees, is the most questionable part of this Book— Mr Robertson the Marshal’s Bailiff, brought papers of application for the discharge of two persons from prison— A man named William Collins, confined for an assault and Battery— The other a woman named Mary Wigfield, for keeping a disorderly house— They have both suffered terms of imprisonment, and their discharge was recommended by some of the judicial Officers— Mr Brent brought papers of two other applications of a similar nature, but for offences of a higher character— From Chester Ford, convicted of Man-Slaughter— The jurymen by whom he was convicted, recommended him to the lenity of the Court, who sentenced him only to one Month’s imprisonment, and a fine of ten dollars— I doubted the expediency of still further mitigating this Sentence, at least for the term of Imprisonment— The other was an application for pardon for a man convicted of Murder in Alabama—forwarded by his Council: whose own Statement of the case makes it a very atrocious murder— I took both these cases for Consideration— Coll. Jones the Adjutant General came for my determination upon a proposed alteration in the regulations of the army, concerning the pay of brevetted Officers in certain cases; and for the papers which had been left with me. It relates to Captains chiefly, who by the existing regulations are allowed the pay of their Brevet rank as Major’s only when they are in command of a Battalion or five Companies— The new regulation will allow it when they are in command of two Companies— I assented to the alteration, and Coll. Jones took the papers— I sent for Mr Elgar, and spoke to him, of a Letter from Mr William Elliot, Secretary to the Columbian Institute concerning some question which Elgar makes objecting to the laying out of their garden, in the rear of the Capitol— It disagrees with the line of the Canal— Elliot proposes that I should appoint certain members of the Institute to report upon it; which Elgar said he should not object to; but he observed that Coll. Roberdeau, had already reported to the Institute, against the Canal. I mentioned also to Mr Elgar, the laying out of the ground fenced off in the yard, for a nursey. He said he would ask Mr Foy to call upon me concerning it— I received and answered a Letter from George— Evening Thunder Shower.
15. III:45— Walk round Tyber Square. Garden— Yard.

Plucked a weed from the yard near the mulberry tree; which Ousley told me was the Hypericum, or St Johns Wort— Planted 11 whole cherries in the Eastern seedling bed. Took 24 black currents from the bush, to sow their seeds— As there was no appearance of vegetation in two of my flower Pots, I turned up the earth in them to examine the condition of the seeds— I found four or five orange seeds without symptom of vegetation, and one with a radicle near two inches long, but no stem nor severance of the seed in two— I recovered it with the earth— The chesnut seemed a little swollen at the germ I replaced it— The Strawberries remained, all the juices of the pulp being withdrawn, an adhesive semblance of skin, with the seeds unaltered in their places without appearance of vegetation— I left the Pot containing the apple pippins exposed for two or three hours this morning to the action of the Sun, made more intense by passing through the window glass— The apple tree which first came up, and which untill then had grown with vigorous and rapid vegetation, began then as rapidly to decline, and this Evening has all the appearance of withering— Du Hamel says that this happens to great multitudes of Plants, without assigning any cause— But I attribute this to the fierce heat of the Sun— The second pippin, which came up yesterday morning, drooped also very much this day, after its exposure, but revived much in the Evening. Mr Taliaferro the member of Congress from Virginia called to visit me. Commodore Tingey also came and informed me that he was going on Monday upon an excursion to Bath in Maine to visit his daughter, Mrs Wingate— He has recently been appointed a Commissioner of the Navy, and has accepted the office upon a sense of duty to hold it, until Commodore Rodgers shall return from
the Mediterranean— But he prefers his station as Commander of the Navy-Yard, and hopes when Rodgers comes back to return to it— Hull perseveringly declined taking the office of a Commissioner; and in asking a furlough, to go with his family to France. Mr Biddle of Philadelphia came, and warmly urged me to attend, at a celebration, in Pennsylvania, upon the opening of the Canal, and to which I am to be invited— I said it might depend upon the time, when it will take place— Governor Barbour mentioned an application, by Coll. C. F. Mercer, in behalf of a Cadet named Cook, whom he supposed to be one of those last sentenced to be dismissed from the Academy, but he was not upon that list, and I have not yet been informed of the proceedings upon his trial— I read to Governor Barbour, my decision upon the cases he had left with me, and he said he would take them to-morrow Morning— Mr Rush brought the first Volume of the American Farmer in which there are directions for the transportation of seeds and plants over sea, similar to those in Dr Lettsom’s Book— Joseph Blunt was here an hour this Evening, having postponed till to morrow his departure for New-York— I examined thoroughly the Plates explanatory of Du Hamel’s second book upon Plantations, and read also part of his Book 4. Ch. 2. on the germination of seeds— I see that germination is a perpetual miracle; and remark the contrast between the interest of the facts recorded in this summary of the operations of nature, and the inanity of all the theories to account for them.
16. III:45. Sun rose 4:34. First Solstice day— Boat with John— Swam 10 Minutes. Garden.

Began reading Du Hamel’s third Book on Plantations—which treats of Nurseries— They must be differently managed for the different kinds of trees that are to be raised for transplantation— Bathed— On landing from the bath I plucked up two plants; one growing on the part of the strand, where the tide flows and one just above the point to which it rises. Ousley told me the first was an Aster and the second he believed a Glycine— I found him budding an Orange tree, in a Pot. Planted 8 whole cherries.— Observed the anemone, and mimosa in his flower pots— Endive, Celery, Turnsole, Basil and Summer Savery, in the Garden—and Spinach— Antoine’s Rose-Laurel he calls Bay-Laurel, or Oleander— The apple pippin which first came up in my flower Pot N 1. this day died— The second yet lives, and two more first appeared, the 3rd. at ten this morning and the 4th. at 7 this Evening. I planted in Pot N. 4. a Pennsylvania Shelbark that I have kept in sand since last Autumn, and six Pippins from a small Apple of this year. Thomas Copeland has been some years employed as a Machinist at the Armoury at Harper’s Ferry. Some complaints were made by him against the Superintendent there, which underwent an investigation by order of the Secretary of War, and the Superintendant was acquitted: upon which Copeland was dismissed— He came to plead his wants and his large family. I referred him to the Secretary of War. Mr Baker came to introduce the Revd. Mr M’Leland, a Presbyterian Clergyman, from the western part of Virginia, near Abingdon, who is returning from the annual Convention at Philadelphia. Jesse Reeder of Cincinnati Ohio, announced himself as the inventor of an instrument to serve as a substitute for the compass to go to the Pole— It consists of a wheel made to revolve once in 24 hours, to which is appended a hollow tube which will indicate the Cardinal Points, by the Sun’s shining constantly through it. He thought this would be a very valuable acquisition to the Government— I asked him how if there should be perpetual fog in the Polar regions— He thought it more probable there was perpetual Sunshine. He appeared not to know that the Magnetic Pole and the Pole of the Earth are wide apart, and had never heard of Churchman’s book. I told him that Captain Parry was now gone, upon an Expedition professedly to the North Pole under the authority of the British Government— That he had sailed from Deptford in April, and if successful according to his plan, must at this moment be within five degrees of the Pole— That the difficulties he had apprehended, and which have arrested all circumpolar Navigators hitherto have been, not the failure of the magnetic needle, but ice— That before the end of the year we shall probably know the result of Parry’s expedition, and could then judge of the utility of his, Reeder’s invention, the ingenuity of which appeared to me unquestionable— He told me he had also invented another instrument, for surveying Lands, and which from his description was like Barnum’s,
and for which he said he should take out a Patent— General Macomb came and took the proceedings of the Court Martial in the cases of the six Cadets, with my written decision upon five of them, the sentence upon the sixth not extending to dismission— The General spoke also of his claim to the pay and emoluments of a Major General, which he is by Brevet; and said the arrears of them amounted already to more than 20,000 dollars— He claims as Chief Engineer, Head of the Ordnance Department, and Chief of the Military Academy at West-Point—all which he thinks quite equivalent to a Major General’s command— Dr Huntt called to ask for a friend of his a specimen of my signature which I gave him, and to recommend to me a journey and relaxation for the restoration of my health— Mr Mercer, member of Congress from Virginia, called to speak in behalf of Cadet Cook, for whom he solicited pardon— His trial has not yet been submitted to me. Migalt was a man who brought a Book called the Young Ladies Astronomy for Sale; and was quite sociable— Mr Rush called to take Dr Mease’s last Letter— I suggested to him the expediency of having an alphabetical List made of the Plants recommended to be imported for cultivation— To be made out in columns shewing the botanical name of the plant—then its trivial name— The country from which it is to be brought—its uses—and the person by whom its importation is recommended— Mr Taliaferro and Mr C. C. Biddle dined with us, and I took an Evening ride, with Mrs Adams, Mary Hellen and Charles

Heard Mr Little this Morning, from 1. Corinthians 1.23. “But we preach Christ crucified, unto the Jews a stumbling block, and unto the Greeks foolishness; 24. But unto them which are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God, and the wisdom of God.” After some historical notices of the occasion upon which this Epistle was written and the purposes of the Apostle in writing it, he gave his own view of the meaning of the text, and argued against the doctrines deduced from it by the Calvinists, and Trinitarians— In the afternoon I went to Mr Baker’s, where after the congregation had been some time assembled Mr Handy gave noticed that there would be no afternoon service; and I attended at St John’s Church, where Mr Drain read the Evening prayers for the first Sunday after Trinity and preached from Psalm 102.26. “They shall perish, but thou shalt endure: yea, all of them shall wax old like a garment; as a vesture shalt thou change them, and they shall be changed. 27. But thou art the same, and thy years shall have no end.” It was a sensible and well written discourse upon the immutability of God. More in the Style of episcopal clergymen, formerly in fashion, than in that which many of them have more recently adopted— It was a regularly divided Sermon, and successively considered the immutability of the divine being in reference to his mercy, his promises and his justice. The preacher was quite a young man, and the modesty of his tone and manner was prepossessing in his favour. In the Evening I heard again Mr Little, from Luke 21.16. [“]And ye shall be betrayed both by Parents, and brethren, and kinsfolks, and friends; and some of you shall they cause to be put to death. 17. And ye shall be hated of all men for my names sake 18. But there shall not an hair of your head perish. 19. In your Patience possess ye your Souls.”— Mr Little admits that Jesus Christ exercised the Power of prophecy and considers this prediction of the destruction of the Temple, as one of the most remarkable instances of it. He alluded to the fact that this Gospel of Luke was published several years before the fulfilment of this prophecy. There is great difficulty in conceding the gift of prophecy, and the power of working miracles with the denial that Christ was more than a human being— Mr Little dwelt not long upon this aspect of his text, but proceeded to the illustration of it, by urging it as an exhortation to firmness and self possession under calumny and persecution. This part of his discourse was impressive and not ineloquent—partaking too much however of that habitual train of thought which pervade almost all of his Sermons— The Morning had been at high Summer heat, as was yesterday and last Night— A short gust; with a light sprinkling of rain, and without thunder, was followed by a North-western breeze, a clear sky, and an evening uncommonly cool for the season— I took a short walk in the Garden this Morning— And read the chapter of Du Hamel’s third Book on Plantations which treats of Nurseries, of the Seasons for planting in them, and of transplanting from them.
18. IV:10. Sun rose 4:34. Swam from Boat, alone. 10 minutes. Garden.

Mr Southard had sent me the papers, relating to the appointment of a paymaster to the marine Corps— Captain Kuhn has held that Office several years under the appointment of Coll. Henderson the present Commander of the Corps. But as he recently brought charges against Henderson, affecting his character in regard to his honour, and integrity, and as the Court of enquiry to which they were submitted, exonerated Henderson he now wishes to remove Kuhn from the Office of paymaster, and wrote to the Secretary of the Navy, to that effect— A correspondence between them ensued the result of which is an opinion of Mr Southard, that the Commandant has not the right of appointing the paymaster, but that he should be appointed by the President during the recess, and by nomination to the Senate, at their Session— The question depends upon the construction of three or four Acts of Congress: which Mr Southard thinks have been incorrectly construed; but upon two of which at least, my opinion inclines to the old Construction— And upon the other I am not entirely without doubt. After discussing the subject with Mr Southard, I requested that there might be a consultation with the members of the Administration, before we undertake to introduce a practice entirely new, and opposite to that which has been long established, and considered as legal, and suggested some modifications as advisable to the Letter which he proposed to send to Coll. Henderson— That Officer indeed in his last Letter to withdraw all those that he had written relating to the subject: upon which further consideration will be proper— Mr Southard had also sent me sometime since a proposed new regulation respecting midshipmen— That all having attained the age of Midshipmen, and been five years in service, should be entitled to an examination; after which they shall receive a new Warrant as passed Midshipmen—with additional pay and rank over all Midshipmen not passed— I agreed to this and requested that an addition to it should be made that no person should receive a Midshipmans warrant under 14 years of age— The papers relating to the trial of Lieutenant Legaré, I had not examined— Mr Rush called only for a moment, to speak of the appointment of a Light House Keeper at Cape Henlopen, and of Letters from W. H. Wells objecting to the appointment of Mr Batson— Mr Rush inclines to the appointment of H. F. Rodney— Mr Brent came with papers from the New-York, South-American Steam-Boat Association, complaining of the Brazilian Government, and a Letter from Mr Charles King to Mr Clay, introducing Mr Chegaray, as the Agent of the Company— He brought also despatches from Mr Gallatin of the 1st. 3d. and 5th. of May— Mr Chegaray afterwards came himself, introduced by Mr Aaron Vail, and with a recommendatory Letter from De Grand. He stated that he had been as the Agent of the Association at Rio de Janeiro and that the Brazilian Government, after encouraging the Company to send a Steam-Boat to navigate the river amazon had refused them that permission to their heavy loss— Mr Slacum our Consul at Buenos Ayres, called to pay a morning visit and said he should go upon an excursion to the North, in about a fortnight— The weather was again so cool, that I took my morning bath in the river alone, and not without hesitation— I then came to the Garden: and planted 12 whole cherries— Held my now customary conference with Ousley the Gardener, who told me the names of several flowers and weeds, some of them perhaps for the fourth or fifth time— It would take me six Months of this listening, from day to day, to know at sight the names of the herbage and Plants, in this single Garden— The Chrysanthemum resembles the Anthemis, and is the common white-weed patricianised into a Garden flower— He had several plants procured from the Dutch Minister, and the names of which he did not know— And there was Balsam, Larkspur, Sympathum, Sweet and everlasting pea. Red single, and white double Holly-hocks in flower, and the double carnation pink, which cannot yield seed— In my old seedling bed, Ousley discovered a plant newly risen which he took for a Lilac, and I discovered one of my Pennsylvania Walnuts which came up yesterday— The only one of at least one hundred nuts and acorns that I planted here last November and December— In my Flower pot, a fifth Apple pippin shewed itself— The second put forth two Apple leaves which should be at right angles with the Cotyledons— These have spread to the size of a common peach kernel, and stand on a stem raised about an inch and a half from the ground— Antoine procured me two quart glass tumblers, and filled them with earth— I put into one of them ten orange seeds one whole Cherry, one Almond, and two cherry stones, which I covered with earth, and placed close to the side of the glass, where I see them, and wish if possible to see the first process of vegetation— I took the idea from Du Hamel’s Book in which he represents it as an easy experiment— I this day finished reading his third Book on Plantations
19. III:30— Sun rose 4:34. Boat bath. Garden.

Mr Fillebrown of the Navy Department came to request an appointment as a Justice of the Peace—there being no person in the Department, having that Commission; whereby they were put to frequent inconvenience, for authentication of papers and administering of Oaths— I took the matter for consideration. Mr Foy called and had conversation with me concerning the plots of ground fenced off in the yard, for a seedling Nursery— I advised with him how to have it laid out—and he agreed with me upon the plan— Central Cross Allies one East and West—one North and South—a border alley round the whole, and the ground laid out in beds, at first all sown to grass— The Beds to be taken in succession, for the plants to be introduced from time to time— I visited with him the front-yard, and examined the places East and West of the House where last November I had with him planted Chesnuts, Acorns and Walnuts, but not one of them appears— They are much overgrown with weeds. Mr Richard Henry Lee brought me a Memorial from a Committee of Citizens of Loudon County, Virginia, for the appointment of an engineer for the survey of a Road from Cumberland to this City. Mr Munro the Postmaster came with the Bills, for the purchase of the Articles of Military Accoutrement, used in our army— They are to be presented to the Grand Duke Constantine, at Warsaw, under whom Mr Munrosson is an Officer— I had consented that they should be paid from the contingent fund of some department, and think it must be that of foreign intercourse. Russell and Cartagena, were two Strangers, who introduced themselves, one as an Irishman having long resided in the Island of Porto-Rico, the other as a Citizen of the Republic of Colombia, who came solely from motives of curiosity— Cartagena speaks no other language than Spanish; wherefore I could hold no discourse with him— They were both men of respectful deportment—and made their visit short. In the garden this morning I mistook the Lupine for the African Marigold, and enquired again the names of several plants which had been repeatedly told me— The French Marigold was shewn me differing altogether from the African— My Pennsylvania Walnut was as yesterday— I planted 11. whole cherries which completed the row— Foy recognized the Oxalis or wood-sorrel, the Echium vulgare or wild bugloss and the Verbascum Blattaria, or Moth Mullein— I planted 12 red cherry-stones entirely fresh—round the sides of a tumbler, filled with earth. The second of my apple pippins, puts forth a third leaf proper; the plume still appearing distinct from them all— Its appearance is extremely frail and delicate, always threatening to wither and perish. The last three came up like the first with the shell yet over the seed— I took one of them off when it remained barely as a cap over the cotyledons, and they parted like the two sides of a pair of pincers relieved from the pressure of an elastic Spring— These last comers are more puny than the first— Three of the Silk-worms came out this Morning as white Moths.
20. IV. Sun rose 4:34. Boat Bath— Garden.

Mr Barrell came to solicit employment for Mr R. Little, the Unitarian Clergyman, and gave me to read a Letter from Mr Little to the Committee of the Society, giving them notice that unless an addition of at least 600 dollars a year to his Salary can be provided he will be obliged to leave the City, and seek subsistence elsewhere. At the last Session of Congress the Bill to appropriate for the service which Mr Little has been performing as Recorder for the Patent-Office, failed, and Mr Clay declines continuing the compensation not authorised by Law— Mr Barrell suggested that Mr Little apprehended Mr Clay was personally unfriendly to him; but I told Mr Barrell that this suspicion was altogether unfounded— Governor Barbour came, and informed me that J. Crowell, the Agent to the Creek Indians was here, having entirely failed, in persuading the Indians to relinquish the remnant of their
Lands, within the State of Georgia— He has also failed in the payment of their annuity of 50000 dollars— Mr Tutt the Commissioner having awarded 20000 dollars of it to the Mackintosh party, as compensation for their losses at the destruction of Mackintosh, and his property— The Little Prince’s party protest against this payment, and claim the whole annuity; and the Mackintosh party refuse to receive the amount awarded them, being threatened with destruction by the others if they should receive it— Mr Crowell was afterwards here, and repeated all this to me— He says that the Indians are much dissatisfied with him, and that they are now much under the influence of the Cherokees Ridge and Vann; who instigate them against him— I conversed with Governor Barbour upon the expediency of making some disposition for an appointment under these circumstances of another Agent, and he proposed Mr T. M. Randolph; but we thought it would deserve some further consideration— I spoke to Governor Barbour also in behalf of Mrs Delage Sumter’sson for a Warrant as a Cadet at West-Point, which he agreed to give for the next year— Crowell told me that the U.S. District Judge for the District of Alabama, Joseph Crawford had decided that the Act of the Legislature of that State extending the Jurisdiction of the State, over the Indian Springs Treaty Lands was unconstitutional and void— Mr Brent brought a Letter from Mr Clay at Union town, requesting that Letters to him should be sent to Wheeling till the 17th. and afterwards to Lexington. Mr Brent also took the last despatches from Mr Gallatin, to send copies of them to Mr Clay. Commodore Bainbridge came and took leave— He has resigned his Office as Commissioner of the Navy Board; and is appointed to the command of the Navy Yard at Philadelphia— He goes the day after to morrow— General Macomb came with Captain M’Neill of the Corps of Engineers just returned from a reconnaissance. Mr Southard brought me several papers, for my perusal, and took the papers relating to the trial of Lieutenant Legaré— The proceedings of the Court martial are to be disapproved for irregularity and Legaré to be dismissed from the service— Coll. Trumbull and Coll. Crowell dined with us— The shoot of an orange seed first appeared this day, in the centre of my flower pot N. 2. the 24th. day since it was planted— I planted 3 whole black Currants in the Eastern, and 2 Apple pippins in the Southern Seed bed— I plucked from the Strand, the antirrhinum or Snapdragon, which is in blossom, and another plant which Ousley did not know.— There are two pair of the Silkworm Moths under glasses— They came out of the Silk worm state last Night, and were quickly paired. And there are two single— Apple pippin N. 4. cast off its shell, but has been so long confined that the seed leaves appear much cramped— I think that by the process of nature the shell should be cast off, before the seed leaves come out of the ground— My second pippin barely lives
21. IV. Cloudy— Sprinkling— Boat Bath— Gale— Garden.

Mr Hill came to solicit an appointment in the Corps of Engineers, if an Act of Congress should be passed for increasing them— He said he had been an Officer in the army during the late War, and had resigned, at the reduction of the army in 1816. I referred him to the Secretary of War, and advised him to make a written application, to be filed in the Department together with any recommendations, that he may produce. Govr. Barbour called and mentioned that Mr T. M. Randolph to whom he had offered a Western Indian Agency, had very unexpectedly left the City without giving him a definitive answer. This makes it necessary to suspend the determination upon the continuance or removal of Coll.
