Crowell, as Agent to the Creeks— I gave the Secretary of War a Letter from Governor Cass, of the Michigan Territory, with Resolutions of the Legislative Council of that Territory, and a Letter from Austin Wing late their Delegate in Congress, all urging with great earnestness the restoration of a Military Post at Prairie du Chien, from which the garrison has lately been removed— Also a Letter from Caleb Atwater of the State of Ohio, concerning Surveys of Roads, and appointments to Office in that State— Governor Barbour will answer as much of these papers as requires answer— Mr Preuss came to renew his application for the appointment of Consul at Dantzig. I told him that on reflection I thought it not expedient to make an immediate appointment to that Office, but that I thought it probable there would be no objection to nominating him for it at the
next Session of the Senate— There was a wretched looking man who announced himself as Saint Peter the prophet and said he was also the Messiah, who talked for a quarter of an hour in the same wild incoherent strain— I asked his name— He said that before he became St. Peter the prophet, his name was Peter M’Dermot, and that he was born in Ireland— Mr Rush came with a question relating to the compensation of the Captains of the Revenue Cutters— By an Act of Congress of 2 March 1799. it is fixed at fifty dollars a Month, and the subsistence of a Captain in the Army— At the last Session of Congress an act passed for allowing to the Captains in the army one additional ration a day—The question was whether the Captains of the Cutters should be allowed the benefit of this augmentation— I thought they should, and the more so, as Mr Rush said they had long complained, of their compensation as inadequate, and it was really less than is received even by the Inspectors of the Customs— I sowed in the Garden this morning ten whole Rasberries, and brought up from the Banks of the river, two Plants, which Ousley told me were the Veronica Scutellata, and an Aster— That which he calls a Lotus is the Field Trefoil— My Apple pippin N. 3 came up so near to N. 2. that it was on the point of interfering with its growth— At the hazard of killing them both, I took up N. 3 and transplanted it, into another flower pot— N. 5 soon after shedding its shell, withered away, and N. 4. is barely living. The Orange shoot comes up differently from the Apples—like a needle with a sharp point pushing upwards. It came out yesterday morning, and its growth is yet scarcely perceptible— One of the Silk worm Moths this day laid 238 eggs. four more of the grubs came out as Moths— We had this day at dinner Apricots—the first of the Season— I signed an order for the remission of the forfeiture of the Ship Philadelphia, J. Welsh owner, for excess of Passengers
22. IV— Boat Bath— Shower. Garden walk prevented.

Mr Brent called to mention an application for a remission of penalty and forfeiture of a British Vessel for bringing an excess of Passengers, but under circumstances different from those upon which the remissions have been granted—particularly by a clandestine landing of the supernumerary passengers— I reserved my decision and gave the papers to Mr Rush to examine and report his opinion upon them— Mr William King of Bath in the State of Maine called, and said he had come to New-York and Philadelphia upon certain business and finding himself thus near had concluded to pay a short visit to Washington— Mr Rush came in while he was here, and hearing speak of his visit as altogether accidental, told me after he was gone, that he had received notice from Bath, that he was coming here upon business of the Bank at that place. Mr King made enquiries respecting the State of the Negotiation with Great Britain upon the North Eastern boundary, to which I told him there was no prospect of an early termination. Mr Brent called a second time and introduced Mr Bayly formerly a Member of Congress from Virginia, who is going upon a Northern Tour, and came merely to make a friendly visit— Coll Hugh Mercer of Virginia came for the same purpose, with his son: a boy of 12 or 13. and another youth named Austin— Mr Boyle, one of the Clerks at the Navy Department, came with two Letters from Mr Southard one to Commodore Chauncey, and one to the Committee of the Citizens at Brooklyn Long Island concerning the title to the Navy-Yard, both of which I approved— He brought also the decision upon the case of Lieutenant Legaré, disapproving the proceedings of the Court Martial which sentenced him to be cashiered; but dismissing him from the Naval Service of the United States— Boyle said that Mr Southard had been these two days ill confined to his house, but was expecting to be out again to-morrow Morning— Johnson Hellen dined abroad— My Morning Baths this day and yesterday have been not so pleasant as usual. Both mornings it blew a gale, and I swam with some difficulty owing to the swell of the river— I have less confidence than heretofore in swimming alone; and less confidence in the good
effect of the Bath upon my health— Both Mornings threatened rain when I went out, and as I returned this Morning, a heavy shower, deprived me of my stroll in the garden— I read a Chapter in Du Hamel’s fourth Book on Plantations— The transformation of the Silk worm grubs into Moths continues. There was no visible growth or alteration in my potted Apple pippins which survive— The orange shoot this day opened into two embryo leaves, with a plume between them scarcely of the consistency of a hair— A second shoot this day appeared at the surface of the ground— I planted an Apricot stone in the centre of a quart Tumbler— The weather cleared off this afternoon— Cold— Mr John Leeds Kerr was one of my morning Visitors—
23. III:30— Sun rose 4:34. Boat Bath— Garden

The Night was almost cold enough for a frost, and after swimming from the Boat to the shore, I was more benumbed in dressing than I had been at any time this Season. In the garden, I planted 12 Apricot Stones, and 13 Black-heart Cherry Stones— I planted also 1. Apricot Stone in the centre of Flower pot. N. 5— I found no new sign of vegetation in the garden— My transplanted Apple plant since its removal has neither grown nor died— Nor has that from the side of which it was taken— The central Orange shoot has more unequivocally opened into two leaves— The second has yet scarcely risen above the surface— I read a Chapter of Du Hamel on Plantations— This Book is upon Nurseries and Transplantations, and although full of useful instruction excites less of my attention than those parts of the work which relate to germination— Mr Ringgold the Marshal came to speak of the Execution of De Vaughn, which was fixed by the Court for next Friday— He supposed I had received a copy of the verdict and sentence, and enquired, if I proposed to grant a pardon or reprieve— I said I had for the present no such intention— I had not received a copy of the proceedings, but had seen in the Newspapers the sentence of death pronounced by judge Cranch— It was a case of most aggravated murder, and there had been no recommendation to mercy, either by the jury or the Court— I had been much distressed by the supplications of the Man’s Sister, who had applied to me in person, and I had received a Memorial from Alexandria, soliciting a reprieve for him, signed by a considerable number of names, but of which I knew scarcely any— He said he should see the judges in Court this Morning, and enquire whether they proposed to recommend him to Mercy— If not, and he should hear no further from me, he should execute the Sentence on Friday, at 2 in the afternoon. Dr Thornton called with a Mr Mendenhall, from North-Carolina, heretofore a Quaker, and a Slave-colonizer— He is going to the Northern States, and to visit the British Provinces of Canada. Mr Bouligny called, on his return from New Orleans. Mr Crowell came to take leave—intending to depart to-morrow, for his residence at the Agency. He recommended sending a company of Soldiers to the vicinity of the agency, for the purpose of keeping effectually the Peace among the Indians— Governor Barbour was afterwards here, and mentioning that Crowell had made the same proposal to him, thought it would be advisable to postpone this movement for the present— But he said he had written to the Little Prince, expostulating with him upon the threats of violence to the Mackintosh party, and also upon the obstinate refusal to cede the remaining strip of their Lands within the State of Georgia— Mr Rush came respecting the appointment of a Register of the Land Office and Receiver of public monies at St. Stephens, Alabama— It has become necessary to remove immediately the present Receiver Conway, and at Mr Graham’s recommendation, a Commission of Receiver is to be sent to the present Register, Hazard, and a brother of Mr Owen the member of Congress is appointed the Register— Mr Rush informed me that Mr William King had applied to him on the affairs of the Bath Bank; and had come strongly fortified with Recommendations. Dr Sewall called, having recently returned from a visit to Hallowell, Maine— He spoke of the Affairs of the Columbian College, and said that their debts were justly chargeable to the general Association of Baptists throughout the United States— That a Committee of three persons had been appointed, who were shortly to meet here and investigate the affairs of the College and make provision for their debts which he had no doubt would all be paid— Mr Rush sent me the London Courier containing the Speech of Lord Grey upon the formation of the new Ministry of Mr Canning—
24. III:45— Sun rose veiled—

Heard Mr Little from Philippians 3.12. [“]Not as though I had already attained, either were already perfect: but I follow after if that I may apprehend that for which also I am apprehended of Christ Jesus. 13. Brethren I could not myself to have apprehended: but this one thing I do, forgetting those things which are behind, and reaching forth unto those things which are before, 14. I press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus.” The discourse was elaborate, to shew that Christianity is essentially a system of improvement— That progressive virtue is its peculiar characteristic— My impression at first was that this position was too obvious to need illustration; but as the argument was ingenious as well as earnest, I came at last to view it as an important aspect of the system. Progressive improvement is indeed the great doctrine of Christianity; as a code of morals, and it is perhaps in no other religion of ethics— In the afternoon I heard a Stranger at Mr Bakers, from Hebrews 2.3 “How shall we escape if we neglect so great Salvation?” A minatory Sermon; but the preacher had little eloquence, and not much Logic— Mr Baker was in the pulpit with him— After dinner I rode with Mrs. Adams round by the Capitol and College Hills, and heard again in the Evening Mr Little from Acts 17.26. [“]And hath made of one blood all nations of men, for to dwell on all the face of the Earth, and hath determined the times before appointed, and the bounds of their habitation; 27 That they should seek the Lord, if haply they might feel after him, and find him though he be not far from every one of us.”— Although the text was changed, the Sermon seemed a continuation of that of the Morning— The Silk worms are now all turned to whitish Moths, are in pairs, and several of them laying eggs nearly white, which from day to day, fade into a dunnish yellow, and darken into brown— My apples tree N. 2 this day shews a fourth leaf proper nearly formed, and now exhibits a perceptible stem above the seed leaves— This is the only one of the five which came up the growth of which has been apparently natural—the seed leaves of the two others yet surviving came up cramped by the shell still covering them, and they never have unfolded themselves perfectly— I infer that by the process of nature, the shell should be cast off, before the seed comes out of the ground.
25. IV. Sun rose 4:34. Walk to the Slashes— Garden.

Mr Green came with a subscription paper, from the Roman Catholic Clergyman, Mr Matthews, the object of which was to raise a Sum of 6000 dollars to erect a building for a School for orphan children, to be kept by the Sisters of the Charity the Nuns of Georgetown— I declined subscribing, but promised to contribute 50 dollars— Mr Dickins came to ask for the volume of Records of the Columbian Institute which had been sent to me by Mr R. Little; and a Messenger from the Treasury afterwards came and took it— Mr Brent mentioned a Letter of 1. March from W. Tudor, received at the Department of State— Governor Barbour came to take leave, going with Mrs Barbour this afternoon for the Bedford Springs in Pennsylvania— Mrs Barbour has just arrived from Virginia— Mr Brent had a Letter from a Coll. Mullany, who was a Quartermaster during the late War— There is difficulty about the Settlement of his Accounts; and he obtained a special Act of Congress, for the adjustment of them by the accounting Officers of the Treasury, upon principles of justice and equity. This gives a sort of discretionary power to the accounting Officers—yet the second Comptroller, found a large balance against Coll. Mullany. He then appealed to the Secretary of War, and then to Mr Clay, whose office has nothing to do with Treasury Accounts, and who referred to the secretary of War his Letter— Mullany had already appealed to me by a Letter received last January, enclosing certificates by a large portion of the delegation of New York in 1818 and 1822, and a recommendation from Genl Scott with a complimentary original Letter from
Mr Monroe— Coll. Mullany now requested that the Letter of Mr Monroe might be returned to him: it was found and given to Mr Brent— Mrs Talbot and her mother Mrs Thomson paid a morning visit to Mrs Adams— Major Nourse, the Chief Clerk of the War Department brought me the papers; proceedings of a Court Martial for the trial of Lieutt. J. J. Schuler; and afterwards sent me the Report of the Visitors at West-Point— Mr Southard brought a Letter from John M’Kim of Baltimore containing complaints and certain enquiries arising from an importation of specie, from Montevideo in the U.S. Ship Cyane, Captain Elliot. Mr Southard has been three days ill, confined to his house— Mrs Adams received a basket of Alberge Plums, brought by Mrs Barbour from Virginia, and some fine Apricots from Coll. Armistead— I have been obliged to suspend my river baths again for some days, and to substitute a morning walk in the fields— I plucked this morning several common plants some of which Ousley could not name— In the garden itself he shewed me the Coxcomb, Marble of Peru, Globe Amaranth, Southerwood, still new to me, and marked the difference between the Cardon, and the Artichoke, for which I had mistaken it— He discovered four of the Pennsylvania Walnuts, which I planted on the 23d. of April, shooting up from the earth— They are yet bare stems, from half an inch to two inches above the surface, and without leaves— Mrs Adams painted for me the Apple tree N. 2, as it now appears in the flour pot— I dug up one of the Spanish Chesnuts planted in April— It had not vegetated and was rotten.
26. IV.— Cloudy— Slashes— Garden— Showers—

In my walk to the fields, I plucked three or four plants, growing wild by the way-side, to ascertain their names— Of Plants which for many years I have trampled under foot, and occasionally noticed; but the names of which I have never known, or had forgotten. This morning I took the Podalyria tinctoria, or Wild Indigo— The Coreopsis verticillata, or Tick-seed Sun-flower— Some leaves of the liquid amber maple-leaved; and one or two more which Ousley did not know— I enquired further of garden plants but only repeated names, told me before— There was a shoot coming up; perhaps a cherry Stone planted 30. May. The plant with a double seed-leaf coming up is a lilac from the seed— The single Pennsylvania walnut in the Southern bed, which came up the 17th. has put forth its leaves vigorously. My pot seedlings remain as yesterday; but I found the Apple-trees would not bear exposure to the strong breeze of wind near the window. There was a moderate thunder shower this Evening.— James Barnes is a Citizen of the interior of Pennsylvania; a visitor for curiosity— Mr Ringgold the Marshal came, with a copy of the Sentence of Death, passed by the Circuit Court of this District upon Jonathan De Vaughn, for the murder of Tobias Martin— It is to be carried into Execution to morrow, between the hours of twelve Noon, and 3. in the afternoon.— The day having been altered, from Friday, at the suggestion of Judge Morsel, who objected to an Execution, upon a Friday— Mr Ringgold said he had been yesterday at Alexandria, and seen De Vaughn; and advised him to prepare for his fate— Assuring him that he had no reason to believe there would be a respite of the Execution. He has until within a very few days, always flattered himself that there would; and he has been reckless of his condition— He is now somewhat softened, and has the spiritual assistance of Mr Cornelius, and of Mr Harrison, Methodist Preachers. He preferred them, though he told Mr Ringgold that he had been bred an Episcopalian— Mr Ringgold said that Mrs Mills, De Vaughn’s Sister, had applied to the judges and to every member of the jury who tried De Vaughn, for a recommendation to mercy; but all had declined giving it— He added that unless he should hear again from me, he proposed to execute the Sentence, as nearly as possible at two O’Clock. PM. to-morrow— I said I did not expect any thing would occur to change my views of my own duty, which were to leave the law to its course— Mr Pleasonton came to mention the appointment of a Light-House keeper at Cape Henlopen— There has been as great a struggle for this Office, as if it had been one upon which the destiny of the Nation depended— A party struggle of the most acrimonious character— The appointment has been for several weeks suspended by the collision— But a Letter from Allan M’Lane the Collector at Newcastle, urges an appointment as necessary, and I came to a decision
in favour of Kendal Batson, the person originally recommended by Mr Pleasonton— But the late keeper of the Light-house was also an Inspector of the Customs and that office I propose should be given to Henry F. Rodney— I directed also the appointment of John Alden Shaw, as keeper of a new Light-House, building at Martinicus Rock in the State of Maine— Mr Brent came to enquire respecting the remission of a penalty, and forfeiture of the Ship Philadelphia, John Welsh owner, Josiah Ames master, for an excess of passengers— I directed the remission of both and signed the order accordingly.— Wrote a few lines this evening but it has become too irksome.
27. III:45— To the Slashes— Garden-walk— Showers

Coll. Henderson, Commander of the Marine Corps introduced to me Captain Stevens of the Navy, who is stationed at the Navy-Yard here— They spoke of the reluctance with which Commodore Tingey quits that station for the Office of Commissioner of the Navy, and of the regrets of the Inhabitants at the Yard, upon his leaving them— Hughes is one of the young Men, recently dismissed from the Military Academy at West Point, by Sentence of a Court Martial for the disorders last Christmas day— He came to complain that he had not had an impartial trial, and recapitulated much of the Evidence which was given upon his trial. His main defence was an attempt to turn the attach upon Lieutenant Thornton, the Officer who accused him, by raising against him a charge of unbecoming conduct in listening at his door— I told him, that whatever representation he wished to make upon the subject must be offered through the War Department; and as he said he had found the Secretary of War was absent, on his arrival, I advised him to apply in writing to General Macomb, who is officially at the head of the West Point Academy. Mr Southard came to say that upon the arrival of Captain Elliot in the Cyane, he had intended to order her immediately to proceed upon her cruize to the coast of Labrador, for the protection of the fisheries— But she needs repairs, which cannot be completed in less than six weeks— The fishery cruize is therefore likely to fail for the present Season— I observed that if the repairs could be completed so that she could sail by the first of August, she should still be despatched, as she would then still have a practicable cruize of two Months; but that she would have then no time to spare— Miss Mary Roberdeau came to pass some days here. I walked this morning to what are called the Slashes, and plucked unknown Plants and weeds as I went. Among them was the Teucrium Canadense, or wild Germander, and the Gnaphalium Uliginosum, or cudweed. A plant called Betony by Mr Ousley, but which I do not find in Bigelow, a Solanum, and leaves of the Liquid amber tree— The plants that grow wild, within the range of my walk, are not numerous, and when I have ascertained the name of one, I find myself surprized to observe how often it recurs— In the garden I planted 12 Armistead Apricot Stones, and 9. Alberge Plum stones— I observed that three more Pennsylvania Walnuts, had come up in my Southern bed— Those in the other bed had scarcely advanced at all since yesterday— In my seedling pot N. 1. came up an Apple pippin N. 6. having cast its shell— The orange shoot grows to a considerable degree; the leaves imperceptibly swelling out. Of the Garden vegetables I this day discovered the Martinia, Vervain and red pepper. I took up this Evening the subject of the Colonial Trade with Great-Britain, which has now for several weeks been overlooked— At two O’Clock this afternoon, Jonathan De Vaughn was hanged at Alexandria, for the murder of Tobias Martin— He was a hardened offender, and is said to have died without giving any signs of remorse—
28. III:30. Shower Bath— Slashes— Garden walk. Evening Company.

Mr George Graham came for my signature to a Proclamation for making a Sale of Lands in the State of Illinois and also to an order for the payment of a quarters Salary, to the Clerks dismissed from the Land-Office— I had directed this on the condition that they should be employed during the time—and I signed the papers. He also took the Letter and Military patent for Land in the Territory of Arkansas which had been sent to an Officer in the late War—who sent back the patent to me requesting it might be exchanged for one of Land in Michigan— But Congress have appropriated no land in Michigan, for military grants— Mr Bouligny came and introduced Mr Alain, a native and wealthy Planter of Louisiana— Mr Brent brought a draft of a Letter to William Tudor, at Lima—directing him to repair to Rio de Janeiro, and enclosing to him a Commission, as Chargé d’Affaires at that Court— I signed also a duplicate of the Commission, and directed Mr Brent to forward both by the earliest possible opportunities. Mrs Harbaugh came with one of her Sons— She said she had been a neighbor of mine when I lived in 4 1/2 Street. She has a large family of children— Her husband is in feeble health, and she has two Sons, for whom she wishes to provide; one as a Midshipman in the Navy—and the other, by copying for any of the Departments, or for me— Coll. Jones brought me the Report of the visitors at West Point for the present year, with sundry accompanying papers. Mr Barrell came and introduced his brother in Law Mr. Ward— Mr Rush came with several papers relating to the Bank at Bath in the State of Maine— A Letter from Joseph F. Wingate, elected to Congress from that District; and a Letter from D. Webster, in favour of the Bank— On the other side a Letter from E. H. requesting caution to withstand the plausible tales of W. King, the president of the Bank, with assurances that in a few days the evidence would be forwarded to prove the deep insolvency of the Bank. Mr Rush barely answered Mr King that he would receive proposals for paying the debt due from the Bank in easy and small successive instalments— I approved this, but told Mr Rush that I believed the Bank insolvent, and that this was the true key to William King’s political conduct for the last nine years— Mrs Adams had an evening party of about 40. persons, Ladies and Gentlemen, among whom Mr and Mrs Rush, Mr Southard, and the visitors from Louisiana— The weather was oppressively sultry— I received a Letter from my Son George, dated last Sunday— After a succession of Colds and Rhumatisms, he has fallen, and taken a severe hurt in the hip— It has swollen, inflamed, and now confines him to his chamber. Mrs. Adams took Dr Huntt’s opinion of the case, as stated in George’s Letter, and concluded to go immediately to Boston, to relieve him— I took this morning a Shower bath, walked to the Slashes and returned to the Garden— I plucked the Smilax or Green briar—two kinds—Apergia or hawkweed—Vaccinium or whortleberry—and in the Garden Indian Catnip and the Bene plant were shewn me, by Ousley— He shewed me also the Bene plant Catnip and Vervain— A fifth Pennsylvania Walnut has come up in my Southern seed bed.
29. III:45.— Slashes— Garden— Cabinet-Meeting— Mrs Adams went for Boston.

Dr Watkins shewed me a Letter from R. Peters junr of Philadelphia, urgently recommending, that I would attend the meeting, for the celebration of the opening of the Pennsylvania Canal— So as to shew myself among the German Farmers, and speak to them in their own language— I told Watkins I was highly obliged to my friends for their good purposes; but that this mode of electioneering suited neither my taste nor my principles— I thought it equally unsuitable to my personal character, and to the station in which I am placed— Watkins gave me also to read, a short Letter from Mr. Clay to him; from Wheeling; about Carter Beverley and General Jackson—
Watkins afterwards came again, and introduced a Mr Starr of Halifax Nova-Scotia, heretofore of Connecticut; whose visit was of pure curiosity— Mr Brent came concerning an application for the appointment of a Consul at Lima, in the place of W. Tudor— I advised to postpone the appointment until Mr Clay’s return here— Mr Anderson the Comptroller came to me in a state of warm excitement at an incident, which has recently occurred at West Point— His ninth Son George W. Anderson, was one of the youths offered for admission to the Academy— One of the regulations directs that no candidate for admission shall be received who is deformed or diseased infectiously, or disqualified by it for military service (1338). In execution of this rule, the Candidates for admission this year, were for the first time required to undergo the inspection of a Surgeon, naked— Three of them, a Son of Mr Clay, a Son of Mr Reed the late Senator from Mississippi, and Anderson refused to submit to this examination, and were not admitted— Mr Anderson shewed me the Letter from his Son, who was at a College in Pennsylvania, soliciting that he would obtain for him a Warrant as a Cadet, and that in which he gives the account of his rejection for refusing to submit to this inspection, and the judge was extremely indignant, at this act of oppression as he considers it— He seemed unwilling to admit the possibility that I should not be as angry at this measure as he was, and could hardly endure the comparative coolness with which I considered it— I told him that I felt some repugnancy to this mode of ascertaining the fact of their bodily soundness, and some surprize at its being thus suddenly introduced. But that before making up my judgment upon it, I must recur to the old principle “Audi alteram partem.” There was a Cabinet Meeting at one O’Clock, upon the question with regard to the appointment of the Staff Officers of the Marine Corps. Whether the appointment is to be made by nomination to the Senate, or whether it is vested by Law in the Commandant. In 1798. the authority was given contingently to the Commandant—but in 1809. in 1814 and more unequivocally in 1817. it appears to have been placed upon the footing of other appointments—to be nominated to the Senate— Yet even in carrying this last Act into Execution the Secretary of the Navy directed the Commandant to make the Appointments and report them to the Department; and sundry subsequent appointments have also been made by the Commandant down to the close of the year 1822— To reverse all this and declare it illegal, in the interval between one Session of Congress and another, upon a pragmatical construction of the Laws opposite to that which was acted upon, apparently upon full deliberation, was concluded not to be advisable— Mr Wirt thought there was danger if the appointments were illegally made, that the sureties to the official bonds, might not be held. But that danger would be the same if the appointment were illegally made by the President and Senate, as if made by the Commandant. It was finally determined that the Secretary of the Navy should inform Coll. Henderson verbally, that it is thought best no change of the appointment should be made before the Session of Congress; and that then some measure should be adopted to remove all ambiguity from the Law— Mrs Adams left the City this day at two O’Clock with Jane Winnull, and John Kirke, to go on with all possible speed to Boston. I missed this morning my shower bath—but walked to the Slashes, and then in the Garden— Planted 6. Henderson Apricot Stones, which completed the row of that fruit, in my eastern seedling bed—and plucked several plants among which was the Persimon tree— In the garden, the Balsam, the Lupine, three Larkspur’s and two Marigolds, are in beautiful Blossom— The five Walnuts in the Southern and four in the Eastern bed, are growing with unequal rapidity. What I took for a cherry was however only a fragment of a broken purslane— My apple pippins in the seedling Pots are thriving— N. 2 is putting forth a fifth leaf proper—the seedling leaves remaining still unaltered— The transplanted tree still lives but has not grown, in its new residence— N. 6 comes up so much later but also more vigorously than the rest— A third Orange shoot has come up. Very close to the first— This has opened and expanded into two leaves which assume a Spoon shape, and are constantly enlarging— Evening very sultry.
30. III. Shower Bath— Walk towards Kalorama. Garden—Evening ride—

Wyer read me a Letter from Francis Williams at London, informing him that his brother Samuel Williams had been compelled to retire from business as a merchant— He has gone through various vicissitudes of Fortune— In 1794. I knew him as Consul of the United States at Hamburg— In 1798 he had the same appointment at London— He was there displaced by Mr Jefferson in 1801. but continued in business as a Commission Merchant, and for twenty years had the reputation and the reality of a splendid fortune— About eighteen Months since he very suddenly and totally failed— Became an English bankrupt, and immediately after recommenced business in partnership with Mr Wiggin— But they have now parted, and Williams retires— Mr Foy had sent me three plans for laying the ground out, that has been fenced in for my nursery. One perfectly simple with only two cross central alleys— The other ornamentally disposed with winding alleys— I fixed upon the first— Mr Pleasonton called and requested me to send to Mr Anderson the Comptroller, a copy of my Letter to them both relating to the settlement of my accounts as a Minister in Europe— He brought with him the Telegraph Newspaper of last Evening, in which were two fresh columns of misrepresentation and falsehood, on the same subject— They refer to a document communicated to Congress in 1822. and from an inaccurate statement in it affirm that I received Salary as Minister to St. Petersburg, and as Minister to Ghent, at the same time— I pointed out to Mr Pleasonton the inaccuracy of the document, but even that did not support the assertion in the Telegraph— Mr Graham came with a Letter from Mr Bartley of Ohio, respecting the removal of the Land Office to Tiffin— He has been there himself and attests the suitableness of the place— Major Nourse came respecting the Report of the Visitors to West-Point, and the application of the late Cadet Hughes for a Commission in the army. Genl. Macomb, and Coll. Thayer the Superintendant of the Academy came in while Nourse was here— I spoke of the new mode of examining the persons of the Candidates for admission to the Academy, as of doubtful expediency— Thayer said it was not for him to judge of the expediency of the regulation— But as it existed he had thought it necessary to require a certificate from a Surgeon, of the soundness of person of the candidate; and the Surgeon would give the certificate only upon his inspection of the person— I thought it would be advisable to modify the execution of the regulation hereafter in such manner as to dispense with any indelicate exposure of the person, and if there should be a necessity for providing against imposition, and the introduction of any diseased person, there might be some additional regulation provided— Dr Niles brought Letters of Recommendation—and came with an application for an appointment as agent for the collection and transmission to the Government of Literary publications at Paris— I told him I believed such an agency would be very useful, but that it would require the sanction of an Act of Congress to authorise— Major Hoops a Military Store keeper at Watervliet in New-York— But having been an Officer in the Revolutionary War, he thinks it is too much duty for one Man to be responsible for the safe keeping of a great mass of Military Stores— He kept me nearly three hours, in laying down the extreme importance of the subject—the imminent and awful danger of the blowing up of the Magazine— The dreadful accidents of that kind which have happened, and the fact which has been stated to him that at this very Arsenal at Watervliet, a Lieutenant in the army did once enter the building with a lighted Segar in his mouth. I advised him to make a written Statement to the Secretary of War, who he thinks as well as Coll. Bomford does not duly estimate his woful forebodings— I rode this Evening with Mary Roberdeau and with Mary and Johnson Hellen.

Day— I rise, usually with the dawn, between three and four O’Clock. Read a Chapter in Du Hamel, as soon as daylight will admit— Bathe and Swim in the river, or walk in the fields—Spend from one to two hours in the garden, planting—stones of Cherries, plums and Apricots, and examining plants with Ousley the Gardner. Breakfast at nine—from ten to five P.M—engaged in business and with visitors— Dine between five and six— Write, part of the Evening, and waste the remainder in idleness till ten, when, or sometimes earlier I retire for the Night— My plantations absorb many hours—
